data.title: When Woody Allen Mattered
data.meta_description: It’s impossible to separate Woody Allen the man from Woody Allen the filmmaker. From the accusations he abused his adopted daughter to the fact he married his stepdaughter, he is not an easy person…
data.text:
It’s impossible to separate Woody Allen the man from Woody Allen the filmmaker. From the accusations he abused his adopted daughter to the fact he married his stepdaughter, he is not an easy person to admire. He did not help his cause with his memoir Apropos of Nothing where he wrote about his wife Soon-Yi, “At the very early stages of our new relationship, when lust reigns supreme…we couldn’t keep our hands off each other.” Yuck.

Still, as the adage goes, we should not confuse the artist with his art. Woody Allen’s influence on popular culture is immeasurable. Without him, we would not have the films of Wes Anderson, Sofia Coppola, Charlie Kaufman, Noah Baumbach, Greta Gerwig, Michel Gondry, Miranda July, Richard Linklater and Judd Apatow. We would not have tv shows like Seinfeld, Curb Your Enthusiasm, It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia and The Larry Sanders Show. Allen mastered the self-deprecating joke, the surrealist set piece, the comedy of neurotic solipsism. He forged an alternative ethos to the macho leading man culture of American movies. He made it cool to be a nerd.

From 1977–1986, Woody Allen had a filmmaking run so impressive it’s been equaled only by the likes of Billy Wilder, Preston Sturges and Frank Capra.
